sections.title: Clinical assessment for facial pain and tension headaches
sections.body: We investigate dental, muscular, and TMJ-related causes of facial pain. The focus is on identifying triggers, protecting teeth and joints, and coordinating care when medical input is needed.
bullets: Structured symptom history to separate dental, muscular, and neurological causes
Jaw, bite, and muscle examination with imaging referral when indicated
Clear escalation guidance if red-flag symptoms appear

sections.title: Assessment before treatment
items: History includes onset, triggers, medications, and prior diagnoses
We check teeth, muscles, and TMJ movement to pinpoint likely sources
Referral for imaging or medical review when symptoms are atypical
Transparent discussion of what dental care can and cannot resolve

sections.title: We listen, examine, and plan next steps
sections.body: Your visit covers detailed symptom mapping, examination of teeth, muscles, and TMJ range, and discussion of conservative measures. If findings suggest non-dental causes, we help you access the right medical pathway.
bullets: Pain history including duration, triggers, and relieving factors
Assessment of bite, soft tissues, and nerve distribution
Consider guards, desensitising care, or physiotherapy for muscular causes
When needed, referral letters for GP, neurology, or imaging
Safety netting advice with clear signs that need urgent attention

sections.title: Patients with persistent facial discomfort
items: Facial aching or tightness linked to clenching or grinding
Headaches around temples or jaw that worsen with chewing
Pain near ear or joint with clicks or limited opening
Unexplained facial sensitivity after dental work
Patients needing guidance on whether dental treatment or medical review is appropriate

sections.title: Assess, stabilise, and coordinate
items: Consultation and examination to identify likely pain sources
Conservative steps: guards, bite adjustments, and self-care where indicated
Medical liaison or imaging if neurological or sinus causes are suspected
Consider therapeutic injectables for muscle-related pain when clinically suitable
Review to check response and adapt the plan
Escalation guidance for red flags such as swelling, fever, or vision changes
sections.strapline: We prioritise safe, reversible measures and coordinate with medical colleagues when needed.

sections.title: Keep symptoms under review
items: Follow self-care, guard use, and medication advice exactly as discussed
Note any changes in pain pattern, range of movement, or swelling
Avoid aggravating habits while tissues settle
Seek urgent advice if you notice spreading swelling, fever, visual changes, or jaw locking

faqs.question: Do all facial pains need dental treatment?
faqs.answer: Not necessarily. We identify whether the cause is dental, muscular, joint-related, or medical. If dentistry is unlikely to help, we signpost you to the right clinician.

faqs.question: Will I need scans?
faqs.answer: Imaging is arranged when examination suggests joint changes, sinus involvement, or other causes that need further investigation.

faqs.question: What if I already wear a guard?
faqs.answer: We review its fit and condition, adjust where needed, and update your plan if symptoms persist.

faqs.question: Are medicines prescribed?
faqs.answer: Short courses or topical agents may be suggested when appropriate, but we focus on reversible measures first and coordinate with your GP if prescription medicines are needed.

faqs.question: When should I seek urgent care?
faqs.answer: Escalate quickly if you notice swelling, fever, spreading redness, visual changes, or sudden difficulty opening your mouth.

sections.title: Book a facial pain consultation
sections.body: Discuss headaches, jaw discomfort, or facial pain with a clinician who prioritises safe diagnosis and conservative care.
